marc:datafield.marc:subfield: William E. Hardy was a resident of Maybinton, Newberry District, South Carolina.

Letters and papers of William E. Hardy, including indentures; personal letters; an account book; bills; Civil War letters written from camps around Richmond and Petersburg, Virginia; business letters; and contracts with freedmen.
Robert Goodloe Harper was a resident of Baltimore, Maryland.

The collection contains a letter, 1818, from Robert Hills concerning construction projects in Baltimore, Maryland; a letter, 1821, from the Italian sculptor Raimondo Trentanove concerning a bust of George Washington; and two business letters.
Elias B. Harrington was a resident of Fayetteville, North Carolina.
Business papers including bills, promissory notes, deeds, other legal documents, and many summonses to appear in court for nonpayment of debts.
David P. Harmon was a resident of Haverhill, Massachusetts; partner in Harmon Kimball & Co.

Collection comprises a letter Harmon wrote from New Orleans to his wife, Almira, while on a business trip. Harmon describes New Orleans as " ... the gayest most disipated and licentious city in the union ...," however, his main topic is his concern that he has not heard from Almira or his partners during the seven weeks that he has been away from home.
Israel W. Hargrove was a Granville County, North Carolina, resident.
Collection includes documents relating to the pardon of Israel W. Hargrove after the Civil War, land deeds, and Hargrove's will, 1867.
George W. Harmon was a resident of Granville, [Pennsylvania?].
Correspondence regarding a judgment against J. F. Esty.
Marion Harland was an author, pseudonym for Mary Virginia Hawes Terhune; from Amelia County, Va.

Letters from Mary Virginia (Hawes) Terhune, including letters, 1843-1857, to school friends and discussing schoolgirl affairs and her attempts at writing. The remainder of the letters, 1896-1913, are to friends and contain reminiscences of Terhune's early life.
Francis Harper was a resident of New Bern (Craven County), North Carolina.
Estate papers referring to the renting of turpentine forest lands and the hiring of African Americans.
Adeline Harlow was a teacher at Limestone Springs Female High School in Spartanburg, South Carolina.

Chiefly letters from Adeline Harlow to family members in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The author described the faculty, students, and local surroundings of Limestone Springs Female High School. Other topics include sermons and illnesses, particularly whooping cough and congestive fever. Ms. Harlow reflected on her home, family and friends in Massachusetts, and condemned a female acquaintance who was apparently an alcoholic. She expressed her belief that wages were better in the South and her desire to live independently. One letter contains a drawing of the floorplan of Limestone Springs Female High School. Collection includes two letters to Dr. F.F. Harlow of Cambridge, one from a friend requesting a favor and one from the Berkshire Medical Institution regarding the loss of a building by fire.
Limestone Springs Female High School (Spartanburg, S.C.)
Benjamin J. Harper was a resident of Preston, [Mississippi?].

A letter, 1848, from Mary T. Harper, concerning family matters, cotton crops, plantation life in Mississippi, and the presidential campaign of 1848; and a letter, 1861, from Benjamin J. Harper, a Confederate soldier.
S. C. Harrington was a resident of Lawrence, Kansas.
Letters introducing a certain Clayton, who had been wounded in the capture of "the Southern ruffian, Titus," to S.C. Harrington's friends and relatives in the East.

Primarily letters addressed to Nancie A. Harriman from Willie Byrd Stevens, a soldier in the 4th Vermont Infantry, 1861-1864. While he was in service in Virginia and Maryland, he was located in Fairfax Co., Yorktown, Aquia Creek, Culpepper, and Port Royal in Virginia and in Annapolis, Maryland. The letters and information filed with the collection indicate Stevens was imprisoned in Richmond, Va. for approximately six months in late 1863 and early 1864, and died after suffering wounds in the battle at Cold Harbor, Va., in June 1864. The collection also includes one poem.
Benjamin Franklin Harris was a resident of Oxford (Granville County), North Carolina.
Letters from merchants or textile manufacturers in North Carolina during the Civil War, concerning business transactions and market conditions during the war and after.
William W. Harllee was a South Carolina legislator, lieutenant-governor, and brigadier general in the Confederate Army.
Applications to Harllee for military appointments; and a letter discussing a project to establish a farm for raising medicinal products.
James Harlan was secretary of the interior of the United States under President Andrew Johnson.
Letter to James Harlan from John A. Strother, a planter in the Mississippi delta, suggesting that unemployed freedmen from Virginia be sent to repair levees on the lower Mississippi.
Robert W. Hargadine was a physician of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Letters and papers of Robert W. Hargadine containing rough notes of a thesis at the University of Pennsylvannia for the degree of doctor of medicine, 1867; personal letters from William M. Nickerson, assistant surgeon on the U.S.S. Pensacola; letters from Annie L. Hargadine describing a European tour, 1869; and Hargadine's appointment as a resident physician at St. Mary's Hospital, Philadelphia, Pennsylvannia.
Julia A. Thorne Harper was the wife of James Harper, founder of Harper and Brothers.
Personal note presenting to De Bost a copy of Woodrow Wilson's biography of George Washington.
